KAILASAM, JJ.] STATE OF KARNATAKA Plaintiff; Versus UNION OF INDIA AND ANOTHER Defendants. •original Suit No. 8 of 1977, decided on November 8, 1977 Fa&ts On 23rd May, I 977, the Central Government appointed a Commission of Inquiry against the Chief Minister of Karnataka setting therein the terms of reference to the Commission. The plaintiff State of Karnataka filed a suit in the Supreme Court of India for a declaration that the appointment of the Commission was illegal and ultra vires on the groUAds (I) that the Com- mission of Inquiry Act, 1952 does not authorise the Central Government to constitute such a Commission in regard to matters falling exclusively within the sphere of the State's legi1dative and executive power; and (2) that if the provisions of the Act do so empower, they are ultra vires for the contravention of the terms of the Constitution as well as the federal structure implicit and accepted as an inviolable basic feature of the Constitution. The plaintiff also contended that since the State Government had also appointed its own Commission, Section 3(I)(b) of the Act prohibits the Central Government from appointing another Commission to "enquire into the same matter" as long as the Commission appointed by the State Government is functioning. The defendant Union of India contended inter alia that since the enquiry against the Chief Minister and certain other Ministers is as individuals and not against the State of Karnataka, the suit was maintainable. Held, per majority (Beg, C. J., Chandrachud, Bhagwati, Untwalia, Shinghal and Jaswant Singh, JJ.) (P. S. Kailasam, J. dissenting), that the suit should be dismissed. I. J. 609 The Uoion of India acting through the Central Government can be aaid to represent the whole of the people of India. The individual States, acting through their Governments and Ministers could be said to represent the people of each individual State and their interests. When differences arise between the representatives of the State and those of the whole people of India on questions of interpretation of the Constitution which must affect the welfare of the whole people and particularly that of the people of the State concerned, it would be too technical an argument that a suit does not lie in such cases under Article 13 l. In the present case, there is a Iis. It would be immaterial as regards the dairns on behalf of either the State or its Government whether the two are distinct juristic entities. Even if they could be, the claim of the Government would be that of the State. (Paras 143 and 144) Observations of Beg, C.J. in State of Rajasthan v. Union of India, (1977) 3 SCC 952, explained. Article 131 is a remnant of ' federalism and should be widely and generously interpreted so as to advance the intended remedy. It can be invoked whenever a State and other States or the Union differ on a question of interpretation of the Constitution so that a decision of it will affect the scope or exercise of governmental powers which are attributes of a State. It makes no difference to the maintainability of the action if the powers of the State are exercised through particular individuals as they necessarily must be. But if any of the organs of the State claims exclusive powers to take cognisance of it, the State, as such, becomes interf'sted in a dispute about the legal competence or extent of powers of one of its organs which . may emerge. The fact that the State acts through its Ministers or officials does not affect the maintainability of the suit. There is nothing in the article itself to debar the State which must always necessarily act through its officials or agents or Ministers suing the Centre not only to protect the officer& or Ministers from being proceeded against in any way by the Central Government but prefer its own claim to exclusive power to deal with him and this is what the plaintiff has done by means of the suit in the present case. (Paras 146 to 151) King Emperor v. Sibnath Banerji, LR 72 IA 241 at 266, explained. Govnnor-General in Council v. Province of Madras, (1943) 5 FCR I; United Provinces v. Governor-General in Council, AIR 1939 FC 58 ; Attorney-General for Victoria at the Relation of Dale v. The Commonwealth, 71 CLR 237 and Attorney-Generalfor Victoria v. The Commonwealth, (1933-1934) 2 CLR 533, referred to. Per Chandrachad, J. Even taking a strictly legalistic view of the matter the preliminary objection of the defendant to the maintainability of the suit ought to be rejected. (Para 161) The jurisdiction conferred on the Supreme Court by Article I 31 of the Constitution should not be t~sted on the anvil of banal rules which are applied under the CPC for determining whether a suit is maintainable. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. The article confers original jurisdiction on the Supreme Court and the commonest form of a legal proceeding which is tried by a court in the exercise of its original jurisdiction is a suit. But a constitutional provision, which confers exclusive jurisdiction on the Supreme Court to entertain disputes of a certain nature jn the exercise of its original jurisdiction, cannot be equated with the provision conferring a right on a civil court to entertain common suits so as to apply to an original proceeding under the article the canons of a suit which is ordinarily triable under Section 15, CPC by a court of the lowest grade competent to try it. By the very terms of the article the sole condition which is required to be satisfied for invoking the original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court is that the dispute between the parties referred to in clauses (a) to (c) must involve a question on which the existence or extent of a legal right depends. The quintessence of the articie is that there has to be a dispute between the parties regarding a question on which the existence or the extent of a legal right depends. A challengP hy the State Government to the authority of the Central Govern- ment to appoint a Commission of Inquiry clearly involves a question on which the existence or extent of the lf'gal right of the Central Government to appoint a Commission depends and that is enough to sustain the pro- ceeding brought by the State. The Constitution has purposefully conferred on the Supreme Court a jurisdiction which is untrammelled by considerations which fetter the jurisdiction of a court of first instance. The very nature of the disputes arising under the article is different both in form and subs- tance from the nature of claims which require adjudication in ordinary suits. (Paras 162 & 163) The Constitution aims at maintaining a fine balance not only betvO,' en the legislature, the executive and the judiciary, but also between the powers of the Central Government and the State Governments as is shown by the Legislative Lists and the executive power of the Central Government and the State Governments in part XI of the Constitution. This is a delicate relationship particularly if different political parties are in power in the Centre and in the States. The object of the article is to provide a high powered machinery for ensuring that the Central and State Governments act within the respective spheres of their authority and do not trespass upon each other's constitutional functions or powers. Therefore, a challenge to the constitutional capacity of the defendant to act in an intended manner is enough to attract the application of the article, particularly when the plaintiff claims that right exclusively for itself. The proceeding cannot be thrown ont on the ground that the impugned order is not calculated to affect or impair a legal right of the plaintiff. (Para 164) A proceeding under Article 131 stands m sharp contrast with an ordinary suit. The proceedings are adjudicatory of the limits of consti- tutional power vested in the Central and State Governments. The competi- tion in such a proceeding is between two or more Governments either the one or the other of which possesses the constitutional power to act . There is no third alternative as in a civil suit the right claimed by the plaintiff may reside neither in him nor in the defendant but in a stranger. In a proceeding under Article 131, denial of the defendant's right carries with it an assertion of the plaintiff's. Union of India, (1977) 3 SCC 592,followed. The palliative of a writ petition under Article 226 which is suggested on behalf of the Union Government in such matters is hardly any substitute for a proceeding wider Article 131. Article 131 contemplates varioua permutations and combinations in the matter of array of parties such as the dispute between one or more States or between the Government of India and a State or the Government of India and a State on the one hand and another State or States on the other and such a dispute cannot be decided by a High Court under Article 226. Disputes of the nature described in Article 131 are generally of an urgent nature and their decision can brook no delay. It is, therefore, expedient in the interests of justice that they should as far as possible be brought before and decided by the Supreme Court so as to obviate dilatoriness and a possible appeal. (Paras 167 and 168) Per Bhagwati, J. Artie!& 131 confers on the Supreme Court excluaive oi:iginal jurisdiction in any dispute (a) between the Government of India and one or more States, or (b) between the Government of India and any State or States on the one side and one or more other States on the other, or (c) between two or more States, if and in so far as the dispute involves any question on which the existence or extent of a legal right depends. It does not lay down any particular mode of proceeding for exercise of the original jurisdiction conferred by it. Part III of the Supreme Court Rules contemplates that the jurisdiction under this article shall be invoked by means of a suit but this is not the requirement of the article and in interpreting it one should not be influenced by considerations of cause of action which are germane in a suit. There are two limitations in regard to a dispute under the article. One is in regard to the parties and the other in regard to the subject-matter. The object of the article is that since in a federal or a quasi-federal structure which the Indian Constitution sets up, disputes may arise between the Government of India and one or morE! States or between two or more States and a forum should be provided for the resolution of such disputes and that the forum should be the highest court so that final adjudication could be achieved expeditiously. The other limitation as to the subject-matter flows from the word£ "if and in so far as the dispute involves any question on which the existence or extent of a legal right depends". While mere wrangles between the Governments have no place under the scheme, when legal as distinct from a mere political issue arises touching upon the existence or extent of the legal right the article is attracted. It is true there is a distinction between "State" and "State Government"; but when any right or capacity or lack of it is attributed to any institution or person acting on behalf of the State, it raises a matter in which the State is involved or concerned. The State would be affected or at any rate interested if its Chief Minister or other Ministers in their capacity as such, are subjected to any unconstitutional exercise of power by the Central Government. If the Central Government were to issue a direction to the Chief Minister or other Ministers to exercise the executive power of the State in a particular manner, the State would be clearly affected and the position is not different if the Central Government instead proceeds to enquire how the executive power of the State is exercised by the Chief Minister and other Ministers ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. In such a case the State could have the locus standi to challenge the action of the Central Government if it is unconstitutional. (Paras 200, 201 and 203) State of Rajasthan v. Union of India, (1977) 3 SCC 592, considered. Poindexter v. Greenlww, 29 L Ed 185, relied on. It is not necessary that the plaintiff should have some legal right of its own to enforce before the suit is instituted under Article 131. What the article requires is that the dispute must be one which involves a question "on which the existence or extent of a legal right depends". The article cannot be construed to confine it to cases which relate to the existence or extent of the legal right of the plaintiff, for, to do so would be to read words in the article which are not there. There is no reference to a suit or cause of action in the article. The article confers jurisdiction on the Supreme Court with reference to the character of the dispute which may be brought before it for adjudication. The plaintiff must of course be a party to the dispute which is only possible if he is affected by it ( even though no legal right of his is infringed). (Para 204) State of Rajasthan v. Union of India, (1977) 3 SCC 592, referred to (The learned Judges' own observations in that case explained). The word "right"· in the article is used in a generic sense. For example, if the State claims to be entitled to legislate exclusively on a particular matter on the ground that it falls within List II of the Seventh Schedule and the Union of India questions this right the dispute is one relating not to any right of the State in the strict sense of the term but to the liberty of the State to legislate on such a matter and it would come directly w.i.thin the terms of the article. A dispute relating to the power of the Union to abolish the legislative assembly of a State or to dissolve it has been held to come within the ambit of the article in State of Rajasthan v. Union of India by· Beg, C. J., Chandrachud and Gupta, JJ. and my- self. (Para 205) It may not be possible to say that by reason of the impugned action of the Central Government in setting up a Commission of Inquiry any legal right of the State is infringed but it is not necessary in order to invoke the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court under the article that the State should be able to show that some legal right of its own is breached. It is enough to show that the State is interested not as a busy body or as a meddlesome interloper, but in a real sense in questioning the power of the Central Government to set up the Commission. In the present case, according to the claim made by the State the Legislature of the State and the State Government alone have power to investigate and control the misuse of governmental power by its Ministers and the Central Government has no power to enquire into it or set up a Commission of Inquiry for that purpose. Such a claim raises a dispute as to the extent of the power of the State and concerns the content of the respective powers of the State and Union and the inter•se relationship between the two entities and the State is vitally interested in it. If the State has sufficient title to challenge the validity of the Union legislation on the ground that it interferes with the exercise of State legislative power, it must follow a fortiori that the State would have locus Jtandi to challenge the unconstitutional exercise of power ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. Therefore, the suit filed by the State against the Union must be held to be maintainable under the article. (Para 206) Attorney General for Victoria v. Tiu Commonwealth, 71 CLR 237 and Attorney Gmeral for Vi&toria v. TJu Commonwealth 52 CLR 533 relied on. Per Kaila•am., J. The executive power of the State is co-extensive with the legislative power of the State. The executive power of the State will be exercised by the Governor with the aid and advice of his Ministers. According to the impugned notification the Commission is appointed for the purpose of making an enquiry into a definite matter of public importance, namely, charges of corruption etc., against the Chief Minister and certain other matters of the State. The enquiry, therefore, is amongst other things regarding the misuse of governmental power and the scope of the enquiry would inevitably involve the functioning of the executive of tpe State. The plea of the State Govern- ment is that its powers are derived from the Constitution and its existence and exercise of powers as executive of the State is guaranteed by the Constitution and the Centre cannot interfere with such exercise of executive functions. When the exercise of the executive functions of the State through its officers is interfered with by the Central Government it cannot be said that the legal right of the State is not affected. {Para 278) Slate of Rajasthan v. Union of India, (1977) 3 SCC 592, referred to. Per Uatwalia, Sbiaghal and Ja•want Singh, JJ. (dissenting) The suit is not maintainable. (Para 208) The concept of State is that by itself it is an ideal person or a legal entity. In relation to the existence of a dispute between Union of India on the one hand and one or more States on the other, the expression used in Article 131 for the former is the Government of India signifying that the dis- pute may be with the Government of India but i:he other party to the dis- pute must be the State only and not any limb of the State such as the Govern- ment, the Legislature or the Judiciary of the State. If there is an invasion of the legal right of the State, the .agency through which the action will be commenced may well be the Government of the State but the right must be of the State. (Para 212) To invoke jurisdiction under the article (a) the dispute must be bet- ween the Government of India and one or more States or between the two or more States; and (b) the dispute must involve any question on which the existence or extent of the legal right depends. In specific terms it has not been stated as to whose legal right the question involved in the dispute must relate to and in what respect. Ordinarily, in any suit the competition is between the plaintiff and the defendant and the plaintiff has to establish his legal right in order to succeed. As against the claim of the plaintiff if the legal right to the defendant is established he is bound to fail. But on failure of either to establish his own legal right the suit will still fail because the plaintiff cannot succeed unless he establishes his legal right. The expression "existence or extent of a legal right" used in the article is meant to bring about this result. (Para 213) Observations of Chandrachud, J. in State of Rajasthan v. Union of India, (1977) 3 SCC 592, 639, dissentedfrom. In the present case, the Commission of Inquiry set up by the Central Governmen: 1s not against the State or the State Government. It is against the Chi~f Minister and other Ministers who are officers of the State. It may be open to them to take the plea in an appropriate proceeding such as a writ petition under Article 226 but the State is in no way entitled to inyoke the original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court under the Article. The argu- ment that the State alone has the right to order an enquiry against its Ministers, that the Centr_al Government has no such right, that the Central Government by setting up the Commission has put an impediment on the right of the State Government to modify or issue any subsequent notification for the purpose of enlarging or clarifying the scope of the enquiry and that therefore the legal right of the State is affected, is without substance. Unless the power exercised by one authority brings about a dispute impinging upon the right of the other authority, the latter cannot come under the article and say that merely because it was within its power to do so its legal right is affected by the illegal exercise of the power by the other authority. The said exercise of the power must directly or by necessary implication affect its legal right. If a restricted meaning were not given to the scope of the suit which can be filed under the article anamolous and absurd results may follow, such as any action taken by the Central Government either under the Act or otherwise against any citizen residing in the State or an officer of the State could be challenged by the institution of a suit under the article by the State on the ground that the action of the Central Government is ultra-vires and without any legal right. All that the State noti- fication empowers its Commission to enquire Into is whether any excessive payment or irregularity was involved. The emphasis is on the· question of observance or non-observance of rules coupled with the question whether certain payments were proper. The question of affixation of responsibility is confined to lapses in the course of those transactions only. But the Central Government notification is meant to enable the Commission appointed to tear down even the veil of apparent legality and regularity which may be worn by some transactions. The object is not only to affix responsibility on individuals who may be really guilty even if a few of them could be said to have been mentioned in the other notification. Such notifications could not justly or fairly be spoken as covering "the same matter". It is left to the Central Commission to determine whenever it is .faced with an objection whether a particular matter has already been properly enquired into by the State Commission. A.s the two notifications authorise enquiries into matters which are substantially different in nature and object, the enquiry by the Central Commission cannot be said to be barred by reason of the appointment of the State Commission. If the objectives are different, the examination of common areas of fact and law for different purposes will still be permissible. (Paras 17, 18, 20, 23 and 24) Per Chandrachud, J. Considering the terms of the notifications issued by the State Govern- ment and the Central Government and the matters into which the respective Commissions are directed to enquire, it is obvious that the object and pur- pose of the two enquiries are basically of a different character._ The enqui- ries highlight the difference and show that they are directed to different ends. The primary object of the State Government in appointing its Commission is to ascertain whether improper or excessive payments were made, undue favours were shown, irregularities or fraud had occurred in the conduct of official business etc., whereas the Commission appointed by the Central Government is specifically directed to enquire "whether the Chief Minister practised favourtism and nepotism in regard to various matters mentioned in the notification. (Para 170) It must also be recognised that it would hardly ever be possible except in Utopian conditions that the State Government will appoint a Com- mission to enquire into acts of corruption, favouritism and nepotism on the part of its Chief Minister though such a situation is theoretically possible. Thus the objection of the State Government that the notification of the Central Government offends against clause (b) of the proviso to Section 3(1) of the Act is factually unfounded and theoretically unsound. {Para 171) The contention that Section 3( I) of the Act shoulc. not be construed as authorising the Central Government to appoint a Commission for the pur- pose of enquiring into the conduct of a sitting Minister and of a State is baseless. Section 3 ( l) empowers the appropriate Government to appoint a Commission of Inquiry for the purpose of making an inquiry into any defi- nite matter of public importance. There is no substance in the contention that the Central Governm~t does riot even possess the power to collect facts in regard to allegations of corruption made by a section of the State Legislature. That power must undoubt€dly be exercised sparingly and with re!.traint because under the guise of directing an inquiry under the sub-section the Central Government cannot interfere with the day-to-day working of the Sta14! Govern- ment. Statutory construction cannot proceed en distrust and suspicion of those who are charged with the duty of administering laws. Section 3(1) must, therefore, receive its proper construction with a reservation that mala- fides vitiate all acts. On this view the c-ontention that Section 3(1) should be read fiown and the impugn€d notification should be set aside as falling out- side t~e scope of that section has to be rejected. (Paras 173, 173A and 174) Per Untwalia, Shinghal and Jaswant Singh, JJ. There is no substance in the contention that the Commissions set up by the State and by the Central Government are to enquire into the same matters. The notification of the State Government has not in terms appoint- ed any Commission for enquiry into matters of alleged corruption, nepotism etc., of the Chief Minister or any other Minister of the plaintiff-State. The items mentioned in the State notification are said to be irregularities com- mitted or excess payments made in certain matters relating to contracts etc., and in none of these clauses is mentioned as to who is said to be responsible for the alleged irregularities or mal-administration. By the terms of reference in the notification issued by the Central Government specific matters relating to acts of nepotism etc., of the Ministers of the State are to be enquired into. If some common,matters are found then the notification issued by the Central Government itself excludes such a matter from the jurisdiction of the Com- mission appointed by it. (Para 242) Per Kailasam, J. The Chief Minister also took shelter behind the federal principles said to be embodied in our Constitution and described them as "the corner- stone of national unity and national integrity". The first question which one must tackle is whether Parliament has the legislative competence to enact the Commissions of Inquiry Act, 1952. The British Crown assumed sovereignty over India from East India Company in 1858 and the British Parliament enacted the first statute for the governance of India Act, 1858 (21 & 22 Viet., 106). The Act provided absolute imperial control without any popular participation in the administration of the country. The powers of the Crown were exercised by the Secretary of State for India assisted by a Council of Members. Subsequently the Indian Councils Act, 1861, 1892 and 1909 were passed. Later on the Government of India Acts 1912 and 1915 were passed by the British Parliament. 250. The Government of India Act, 1919, was the first step taken by the British Government for increasing the association of Indians in every branch of administration and the gradual development of self-governing institutions with a view to progressive realisation of responsible Government in British India. Under the Act of 1919 the provinces were delegates of the Centre and the Central Legislature retained the power to legislate for the whole of India relating to any subject. The passing of the Government of India Act, 1935 introduced. for the first time a change in the form of the Government i.e. the Government which was unitary under the Government of India Act, 1919 gave way to a federation with the provinces and the Indian State as the units. Under the unitary system the provinces were under the administrative as well as the legislative control of the Central Government. The Governor-General in Council was the keystone of the whole constitutional edifice and the British Parliament discharged its responsibility through the Secretary of State ,and the Governor-General in Council. 251. The intention of the Government of India Act, 1935 was to unite the provinces and the Indian States into a federation under the Crown. The unitary State was to be broken into a number of autonomous provinces deriving their authority directly from the Crown instead of from the Central Government and then building them up into a federal structure in which both the federal and provincial Governments would get powers directly from the Crown. The basis of the change is the resumption into the hands of the Crown all rights, authority and jurisdiction in or over the territories of the British India and redistribution of the powers between the Central Govern- ment and the provinces. Though the federal structure contemplated under the Government of India Act, 1935 did not come into existence as the Indian States refused to join the federation, so far as the provinces were concerned it took effect. The Government of India Act, 1935 divided legislative powers between the central and the provincial Legislatures and within its defined sphere, the provinces were no longer delegates of the Central Government but were autonomous units of administration. The Government of India assumed the role of the federal Government. With regard to provincial Governments the executive authority of the provinces was exercised by the Governor on behalf of the Crown and not as a subordinate of. the Governor-General, with the advice of Ministers responsible to the Legislature. In the Centre the executive authority was vested with the Governor-General and with regard to reseTved subjects, defence, external affairs, etc. the Governor-General was to act in his discretion, with the help of counsellors appointed by him without being responsible to the Legislature. Governor- General was to act on the advice of the Council of Ministers who were responsible to the Legislature with regard to subjects other than reserved subjects. The Governor-General was to act under the control and directions of the Secretary of State regarding his special responsibilities. The Govern- ment of India Act, 1935 distributed the powers between the federal Legislature and the provincial Governments by having (i) Federal List over which the Federal Legislature had exclusive pQ..wers of legislation ; (ii) A Provincial List over which the Provincial Legislature had exclusive jurisdic- tion; and (iii) A Concurrent List over which both the Federal and Provincial Legislatures had competence. The federal law prevail~d over a provincial law if there was any repugnancy and the residuary power of legislation under the 1935 Act vested with the Governor-General. Under the scheme, the legislative powers of both the central and provincial Legislatures were subject to various limitations and either of them was not a sovereign Legislature. The Indian Independence Act, 1947 was passed as an interim measure before the coming into force of the Con'stitution. The object of the Indian Independence Act, 1947 as amended by Adaptation Orders was to make provisions for an interim Constitution until the Constituent Assembly could draw up a future Constitution. Indian Independence Act, 1947 altered the constit~tional position by declaring that with effect from August 15, 194 7 the suzerainty of the British Crown over the Indian States would lapse and from that date United Kingdom would cease to have any responsibility in respect of the Government of the territories included in British India. The Central Legislature of India ceased to exist from August 14, 1947. The Constituent Assembly came into existence for framing of the Constitution and also functioned as the Central Legislature of the Dominion. The new Constitution adopted the bulk of the provisions of the Government of India Act, 1935. The provisions relating to distribution of powers between the units and the, Centre were adopted and in fact extended. The Constitution-makers gave up the unitary bias and adopted detailed provisions regarding the distribution of powers and functions between the Union and the States in all aspects of their administrative and other activities. Inter-State relations, co-ordination and adjudication of disputes amongst the States were also provided for. 253. The Indian Constitution cannot be described as a federal Consti- tution as the Indian Federation is not a result of an agreement by various States and the territorial integrity of the States is not guaranteed as the territories of the States can be changed or a State completely abolished under Article 4 of the Constitution. But it has to be borne in mind that after the lapse of paramountcy of the British Crown, the Indian States acceded to the Dominion of India were brought within the Union envisaged by the Consti- tution. The Indian States which acceded to the Dominion were brought under the federal system on the same footing as other Units of the Federation, namely the Provinces. The position of the States in the Constitution is in several respects subordinate to the Central Government in that the formation of the federadon was not as a result of any treaty between the States and the federation, and that the State may be reformed or altogether eliminated under Article 4 of the Constitution. Though the Constitution divides executive power between the Union and the States, the States are bound to execute certain directions of the Union. The executive power regarding the laws made by the Union in the Concurrent subjects will be exercised by the States unless the Parliament directs otherwise and as regards the Union subjects the Union may delegate its executive functions to a State either by legislation by Parlia1nent or by consent of the State Govern~ent. It is a duty of the State to execute the Union law and the executive power of the State must be exercised in such manner as not to interfere with the executive power of the Union and the State shall be under the direction of the Union regarding the Union laws. The failure of the State to carry out the directions of the Union would empower the Union to supersede the State Government by assuming to itself the powers of the State Government. These features make the Constitution strictly not a federal Constitution. It has been variously called as quasi-federal or federal in structure or federal system with a strong central bias. Section 10 of the J ammu and Kashmir Act is similar to the present Sections 8B and 8C of the Commissions of Inquiry Act, 1952. The section states that if at any stage o( the inquiry the Commission considers it necessary to inquire into the conduct of any person or is of opinion that the reputation of any person is likely to be prejudicially affected by the inquiry the Commission shall give to that person a reasonable opportunity of being heard in the inquiry and to produce evidence in his defence. Basing on the wording of the section it was submitted that the inquiry is normally only into a definite matter of public importance and inquiries into the conduct of a person can arise only as in- cidental or ancillary to such an inquiry.
